Comment: I have just ridden my motorcycle through OR, NV, AZ, UT, ID and back home to WA, again.  There is, almost literally, nothing out there, the land is generally completely inhospitable: baked dry, poor soil or lava fields, no water, no infrastructure except slab freeway, isolated communities left over from days long past. Much of it seems completely inaccessible. Some of it is, however, quite beautiful, for example the North East corner of OR around Baker City as just one example.  It is hard to imagine any use for much of this beyond solar and wind farms, especially as climate change progresses. Which leads me to conclude that this action will merely lead to the expansion of the current ‚Äúheat islands‚Äù, like Reno, Vegas and Phoenix, the loss of the more attractive areas to Billionaire bunkers, shutting out the people‚Äôs access, and endless legal fights over water rights. Comment: The state I am from is one of those states as well and they‚Äôve been allowing rich landowners to buy up land surrounding huge chunks of public land but we could still access it through corner cutting or walking section lines. Then they were lobbied by the landowners to make corner crossing and implied easements illegal. Effectively controlling thousands of acres of land but only actually owning hundreds.  I used to be able to easily hunt every year and could even go to Walmart and get a deer tag. Now it‚Äôs all a draw system and the state is full of out of state trophy hunters and commercial hunting operations that charge thousands to hunt. You used to be able to call up or stop by and talk to the landowner to ask to hunt their land and many said yes. Now the land is held in trusts or by corporations and you can‚Äôt even find the owner. I had to put in for a draw and fail for two years before even having enough preference points to be successful.   The average person is being locked out, and priced out, of everything.

Comment: Your comment stuck with my while I was making breakfast and for some reason I really started thinking about it. My kneejerk reaction was that I'm talking about nature, you're talking about urban communities so they're totally different things - but these processes are actually really similar and your response here is totally logical. But... I feel like there are two levels to these processes. (And apologize if this is too much, I teach geography and am too into these things).  In both nature and the urban context, the government could claim eminent domain and take over. At that level, we could reclaim either the freeway or partially developed rural land, sure. My first comment was focused on this level and so wasn‚Äôt quite communicating the main point... and that being said, the spatial scales and current times would make buybacks of 1000s of subdivided acres more complicated now than it was in the 60s or 70s when eminent domain claimed was used to displace urban neighborhoods.  But I also think it's true in both cases that after doing that - what's there before couldn't be restored - and that's part of what I was pointing out for rural/natural areas. Obviously that's true for urban areas too - say the government has claimed a large section of a neighborhood/split a neighborhood in two to build a freeway, then the freeway is built, then it's decided that the government shouldn't have done that. What ends up being built in that space? Is it the same landowners, buildings, and community as before? I can't imagine it would be. It might be a new park, or new apartment blocks, etc... but it's not going to be the same houses and people that were there before. Same goes for open space/nature/wasteland whatever you want to call it in nature - it could be sold off and then reclaimed by the government and made public again, but what's there will not (on any reasonable time scale) return to what was there before.

Comment: Constitutionally, Eminent Domain has to provide a fair market value price.  If the US sells a national park, in order for the US to eminent Domain it, the US would have to pay the Billion Dollar value of all the natural resources and what that land would be worth in the open market.    If the US was selling the land at fair market value, it would still be horrible but would be a wash.  If the US sells that land at a discount to rich friends of the administration, well, the US will have to pay outrageous prices to get it back.

Comment: The rot that you‚Äôre speaking of has been the results of an incredibly long game that started in the 70s, and the damage that has been done will still be under repair when I‚Äôm Trumps age.  (I‚Äôm 50ish)  I‚Äôm pretty clear eyed on how we got here.    The OC was ‚ÄúAmericans are doing nothing‚Äù and I will still contend that is flatly wrong.   The administration is being sued every time they do something and largely losing.   Large protests are underway.  General strikes are being called for by even some editorials in traditionally  conservative media like WSJ and Financial Times.  Our media is largely captured by capitalistic interests, an inherit feature of fascism/authoritarianism, and not widely reporting dissent in every day people.  This country has been incredibly damaged in a short time span.  The people are more aware than you‚Äôre being lead to believe.   We may be a largely ignorant people but we aren‚Äôt dumb. (god, let‚Äôs hopeü§û)  These fixes won‚Äôt come fast, it‚Äôs already been destructive to peoples lives.     But ‚ÄúAmericans are doing nothing‚Äù is a false statement.  (If you‚Äôre one of those people that are suggesting this become an armed conflict, explain how you aren‚Äôt an agent provocateur or other accelerationist.)
